Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The National Geospatial Technology Center of Excellence (GeoTech Center) has developed a course content tool and professional educators from across the country composed 10 model courses for geospatial technologies. While these model courses are full classes ready to be offered to students, a larger segment of the geospatial community is composed of those already employed. For this population, a personal assessment tool has been developed, which recommends educational needs when deficiencies arise. It is anticipated that many of the clients will be those preparing to take GIS Certification Institute (GISCI) Geospatial Core Technical Knowledge Exam (GISP Exam). The material developed will provide foundation skills. The personal assessment instrument will make recommendations in 43 sub-content areas on the individual skills. This project will survey geoprofessionals both through online and phone surveys. From the results of the research, the GeoTech Center will learn how to best meet the needs of professionals and to move into a different revenue model. The assessment instrument and the created learning aides will lead to a better prepared and more skilled workforce in geospatial technologies.

A shift in the way professional development is delivered is envisioned in this project. This project seeks to move from employer-based, one-size-fits-all learning, to a model of prescriptive learning based upon a personal assessment. The queries are clearly defined based upon nationally recognized standards in geospatial technologies and have been vetted by more than 200 professionals. The standards are consolidated into 43 sub-categories and an individualized response is generated for participants, which includes recommendations of what is needed. This shift in professional development will lead to more technicians/technologists being successful in taking the GISP Exam and receiving their certification which will improve their level of employment and make advancements possible. For those not interested in this certification, it will provide a measure of their current knowledge and ways to improve their skill sets. A secondary impact will be a transformation of how knowledge is made available to other technical professions based upon proven national standards. It is believed that other educators can emulate this work.

Institution.Name: Kentucky Community & Technical College System
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: KENTUCKY COMMUNITY AND TECHNICAL COLLEGE SYSTEM

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The GeoTeam, researched the needs of the geospatial community and the incumbent workforce.  Geospatial Information, Science and Technology (GIST) is a relatively new field of study when compared to many other STEM areas.  This industry also has a large component of the workforce, which work outside their formal educational discipline.  The National Geospatial Technology Center of Excellence (GeoTech Center) developed an in-depth understanding of the GIST field of study, through the development of the Geospatial Technology Competency Model (GTCM) and the Geospatial Course Content Tool, but did not assess the needs of the individual incumbent worker.  In parallel work, the GIS Certification Institute (GISCI) composed a new certificate exam of skills.  The research of this grant allowed for an understanding of the needs of the incumbent worker verses the institutional requirements. 

The research involved the creation and utilization of a personal assessment instrument composed of more than 180 prompts, which were then categorized in to 43 geospatial content areas.  The individual results are transmitted to the participant via email.  The data of all participants is collected anonymously and analyzed to create a clear understanding of strengths and weaknesses.  To date more than 225 individuals have participated in the personal assessment.  The results were cross referenced with the content taught in higher education classroom.  In additon more than 120 personal interviews were conducted to further understand the pain of the individuals and their wants and needs.

As a result of this research, which is on going, it was determined that the individuals needed a practice exam to prepare them for the needs of certification.  Utilizing good educational practices, the exam needed to be more than just a set of questions. What was needed was content that prepared the individual both for certification as well as long term concept gain.  To this end, a practice exam and study guide are being composed on a dynamic platform to assist in a better learning experience for the incumbent workforce.  The individual gains can be demonstrated through the passing and certifying of their skills.

In addition the 43 competencies are being redefined to include actionable wording at an appropriate depth level to insure that educational institutions and the employers expectations are aligned.

The results of this research will be composed into a White Paper in the future and distributed through the GeoTech Center website,

 


Last Modified: 08/22/2017
Modified by: Vincent A Dinoto
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The GeoTeam, researched the needs of the geospatial community and the incumbent workforce. Geospatial Information, Science and Technology (GIST) is a relatively new field of study when compared to many other STEM areas. This industry also has a large component of the workforce, which work outside their formal educational discipline. The National Geospatial Technology Center of Excellence (GeoTech Center) developed an in-depth understanding of the GIST field of study, through the development of the Geospatial Technology Competency Model (GTCM) and the Geospatial Course Content Tool, but did not assess the needs of the individual incumbent worker. In parallel work, the GIS Certification Institute (GISCI) composed a new certificate exam of skills. The research of this grant allowed for an understanding of the needs of the incumbent worker verses the institutional requirements. The research involved the creation and utilization of a personal assessment instrument composed of more than 180 prompts, which were then categorized in to 43 geospatial content areas. The individual results are transmitted to the participant via email. The data of all participants is collected anonymously and analyzed to create a clear understanding of strengths and weaknesses. To date more than 225 individuals have participated in the personal assessment. The results were cross referenced with the content taught in higher education classroom. In additon more than 120 personal interviews were conducted to further understand the pain of the individuals and their wants and needs. As a result of this research, which is on going, it was determined that the individuals needed a practice exam to prepare them for the needs of certification. Utilizing good educational practices, the exam needed to be more than just a set of questions. What was needed was content that prepared the individual both for certification as well as long term concept gain. To this end, a practice exam and study guide are being composed on a dynamic platform to assist in a better learning experience for the incumbent workforce. The individual gains can be demonstrated through the passing and certifying of their skills. In addition the 43 competencies are being redefined to include actionable wording at an appropriate depth level to insure that educational institutions and the employers expectations are aligned.
